title: On the crest of a wave: British boatbuilders' output up
text:
0.0001 0.0000 
Number of leisure craft built in Britain tops 10,000, but growth at top and bottom of sector reveals 'squeezed middle' 
Britain’s boatyards have increased production, with more than 10,000 new dinghies, yachts and powerboats going down slipways last year. 
In total, UK boatbuilders raised production of leisure craft by 4.3pc to 10,120 vessels in 2014, ranging from 8ft racing dinghies to 150ft superyachts. 
According to data from industry association British Marine , of the £2.93bn turned over by its more than 1,600 mainly SME and micro-business members who together employ 31,500 people in the UK, almost a third of the revenue comes from boat production. 
• From work to leisure: How British shipbuilding has transformed 
The area that saw the strongest growth was the 80ft or longer luxury motoryacht sector, with output of these multi-million pound ships rising by 10pc to 55, according to British Marine. 
Jointly responsibly for all British production in this class were South Coast-based based companies Princess , whose flagship is the 131ft M40, and Sunseeker , which earlier this year launched its biggest-ever vessel, which measures 155ft in length and has three decks. 
By volume, the largest sector was sailboats measuring between 8ft and 24ft in length, with 7,770 of them produced, a rise of 7.2pc. Britain’s strong heritage in racing these small boats makes it an important player on the global dinghy market, and UK production is dominated by three main players, Laser Performance , Topper International and RS Sailing , which build in the thousands. 
However, British Marine’s data revealed a “squeezed middle” in the industry with strong growth in the smallest and largest sectors, while just 100 sailboats measuring 25ft or longer more were built last year. Production of motorboats between 25ft and 79ft fell by more than 7pc on the previous year to a total of 820 in 2014. The association’s data also showed that almost 1,200 boats in other classes, including rigid inflatables, were built in 2014 in the UK last year.
